An open letter to the mayor of NYC
 Dear Mayor Adams,
My name is , a resident of  and I am writing this letter to raise concern about the high number of car crashes in New York City that have resulted in injuries or deaths. Based on 2020 data gathered from NYC Open Data, it‚Äôs clear that this is a pressing issue that needs immediate attention. The following are some startling statistics from the data:
33,442 crashes in 2020 that resulted in either injury or death. Of these, - 9,137 crashes were attributed to driver inattention/distraction - 1,414 crashes were attributed to unsafe speed - 532 crashes were attributed to alcohol involvement

To address this, I urge the city to consider stricter traffic enforcement, improved road infrastructure, and/or public awareness campaigns.
Vision Zero, the city‚Äôs current citywide initiative to eliminate death and serious injuries from traffic incidents, isn‚Äôt enough.
Thank you for your attention to this important matter.
Sincerely,

title: Data
text:
The Motor Vehicle Collisions - Crashes dataset is sourced from the New York City Police Department (NYPD) and is available on the NYC Open Data platform. This dataset provides detailed information on motor vehicle collisions reported to the NYPD across New York City. The police report (MV104-AN) is required to be filled out for collisions where someone is injured or killed, or where there is at least $1000 worth of damage.
The entire dataset, which spans a decade, has 2.16 million entries. Therefore, only crash data from the year 2020 was extacted and downloaded in CSV format, resulting in 113,173 entries. After converting to points in ESRI‚Äôs ArcGIS Pro, only those crashes that resulted in injury or death were extracted, which shrunk the data to 33,442 points, a more manageable size.
The following table explains each column of the original dataset:







Column Name
Column Description




COLLISION_ID
Unique record code generated by system


ACCIDENT_DATE
Occurrence date of collision


ACCIDENT_TIME
Occurrence time of collision


BOROUGH
Borough where collision occurred


ZIP_CODE
Postal code of incident occurrence


LATITUDE
Latitude coordinate for Global Coordinate System, WGS 1984, decimal degrees (EPSG 4326)


LONGITUDE
Longitude coordinate for Global Coordinate System, WGS 1984, decimal degrees (EPSG 4326)


LOCATION
Latitude , Longitude pair


ON_STREET_NAME
Street on which the collision occurred


CROSS_STREET_NAME
Nearest cross street to the collision


OFF_STREET_NAME
Street address if known
